title.narrative: Peace and Stabilisation Programme Horn of Africa 2018-2022

description.narrative: Denmark's Peace and Stabilisation Programme for the Horn of Africa 2018-2022 covers Ethiopia, Kenya and Somalia with a special focus on the ongoing conflict in Somalia, recognizing its regional consequences.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

description.narrative: FL §06.32.08.80 Global Framework for Integrated Stabilisation Efforts (development assistance)

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Output 1.3 Capacity of competent authorities to supervise compliance by reporting entities improved
Number of sectors of reporting entities supervised for AML/CFT compliance

target.value: 2 sectors supervised for AML/CFT compliance

actual.value: 1 sector (in banking) was supervised for compliance (2 in total)

target.value: 4 sectors supervised for AML/CFT compliance

actual.value: 1 sector supervised (3 in total). Only banks were supervised. Standard operating procedures for the supervision of all Designated Non-Financial Businesses and Professionals developed.

target.value: 7 sectors supervised for AML/CFT compliance

actual.value: 2 sectors have and will be supervised (9 in total). Banks and the DNFBPs sectors has been and will be supervised.

target.value: 6 sectors supervised for AML/CFT compliance

actual.value: 4 sector supervised (7 in total). These sectors included real estate (26 agencies), micro finances (18 micro finances) and insurance companies (18 companies). SOPs for compliance supervision of all DNFBPs submitted to FIS. Supervisory authorities for all DNFBPs except for lawyers trained.

title.narrative: Output 1.4 Secure, searchable and consolidated beneficial ownership database on legal persons and entities prepared and in use
Degree (%) to which consolidated searchable database of beneficial ownership of legal persons and entities exists and is used

target.value: 25% Law creates a Registry of corporations and other legal entities/persons

actual.value: 10%: Policy and institutional status on beneficial ownership of legal entities updated. Awareness of the significance of identification and documentation of beneficial ownership raised. Awareness of the signifcance of beneficial ownership data beyond the extractive sector

target.value: 40% Legislation to establish and update register of beneficial ownership of legal persons and entities adopted

actual.value: Experts have developed and delivered the framework for a BO database of legal entities; provisions for the necessary legislative reform have been submitted to the AG’s Office. Workshops on how to use the framework held.

target.value: 70% Searchable register of beneficial ownership of most legal persons and entities established and in use

actual.value: In progress: Estimated 60% completed: Framework for a BO database of legal entities developed; provisions for the necessary legislative reform have been submitted to the MoJ. Database is being ‘populated’ by the MoT.

target.value: 100% Searchable register of beneficial ownership of all legal persons and entities established, updated and in use

title.narrative: Output 3.1: Capacity to manage and implement measures to curb IFFs strengthened
Degree of implementation of systems developed for use by the Ministry of Revenues, the Customs Commission and the police to detect and intercept illicit cross-border transactions

target.value: 25% TfP Unit established and Standard Operating Manuals developed and in general use against cross-border IFFs.

actual.value: 15%: TfP had been established by the time the project commenced

target.value: 70% Transfer Pricing Unit established to implement legislation to curb IFFs, Standard Operating Manuals developed and in general use against cross-border IFFs, membership of multilateral organisations on sharing information relevant to IFFs

actual.value: Delayed. Estimated progress 50%. TfP unit is in existence. Its technical capacity needs have not yet been established. There has been no additional membership of multilateral organizations relevant to the reduction of IFFs.

target.value: 50% TfP Unit established, Standard Operating Manuals developed and in general use against cross-border IFFs, membership of multilateral organisations on sharing information relevant to IFFs

actual.value: Delayed. TfP unit is in existence. Its technical capacity needs have not yet been established. No additional membership of multilateral organisations

target.value: 100% MLAs retained, 2 SOPs usable to tackle cross border IFFs developed, including handling MLA requests (both outgoing and incoming), case management, and case prioritisation

title.narrative: Output 2.3: Capacity of federal and regional investigators to recover the proceeds of economic and financial crimes enhanced
# investigators from the FBI and police officers from regional states trained in recovering proceeds of financial crimes

target.value: 15 Investigators from the FBI and police officers from regional states trained in recovering proceeds of financial crimes

actual.value: 25 investigators trained in the basic concepts of recovery of proceeds of crime

target.value: 50 Investigators from the FBI and police officers from regional states trained in recovering proceeds of financial crimes

actual.value: 50 investigators from the FBI and police officers from regional states trained in recovering proceeds of financial crimes. Furtermore, 15 investigators from the ARD were trained in an intensive 8 week programme

target.value: 75 Investigators from the FBI and police officers from regional states trained in recovering proceeds of financial crimes

actual.value: 56 investigators from the FBI and EPU trained. 40 practitioners from the ARD trained in the recovery of proceeds of financial crimes. 23 judges trained at the request of the judiciary.

target.value: 100 Investigators from the FBI and police officers from regional states trained in recovering proceeds of financial crimes

title.narrative: Output 2.5: Capacity of Ethiopia Police University (EPU) to train federal and regional police investigators on financial crime, ML and FT enhanced
# of EPU staff trained to train financial crime investigators

target.value: 80 students from all regional training centres, trained in 2 training streams of a month’s duration

actual.value: 56 students from financial investigation directorates and regional police training centres trained.

target.value: 50 students from all regional training centres, trained in 2 training streams of a month’s duration

actual.value: 80 police officials provided with technical training in financial crime, anti-money laundering and conterring terrorist financing at the Ethiopia Police University College

target.value: 50 students from all regional training centres, trained in 2 training streams of a month’s duration

actual.value: 80 students from regional centres trained so far.

target.value: 80 students from all regional training centres, trained in 2 training streams of a month’s duration

title.narrative: Output 1.2 Case management system to document, store, process, and track international cooperation (MLA, extradition, or other informal requests) in ML and FT cases established in the FIC, FBI, and AG’s Office

Existence of coordinated case management systems at the AG’s Office, FIC and the FBI which support domestic and international cooperation (MLA, extradition, or other informal requests) in ML and FT cases.

target.value: No case management system linking FIC, FBI and AG’s databases

actual.value: Consultants will be appointed on short term contracts to create an integrated case management system by the end of 2020

target.value: 2 Case management system linking FIC, FBI and AG’s databases established

actual.value: In progress: The framework for a case management system was developed in Q3. Training on its use was delivered in September 2021. The system is being established.

target.value: Case management system extended to include IFFs
1 Case management system linking FIC, FBI and AG’s databases established

actual.value: The project has now appointed an expert to develop the case management system with the FIC, AGs Office and the federal police. Commencement mid-February 2021

title.narrative: Output 2.1: Capacity of FIC's ability to prepare quality disseminations improved
Number of disseminations submitted to ML/FT investigating authorities

target.value: 50 Disseminations submitted to ML/FT investigating authorities

actual.value: 119 disseminations submitted to ML/FT investigating authorities

target.value: 100 Disseminations submitted to ML/FT investigating authorities

actual.value: 136 disseminations submitted to ML/FT investigating authorities in 2021.

target.value: 40 Disseminations submitted to ML/FT investigating authorities

actual.value: Data on disseminations is in the custody of the EFIC. the Project supported the Financial Intelligence Centre, through the 3 day training workshops which combinined investigators, financial intelligence analysts and prosecutors. The training covered current methods to tackle money laundering and terrorist financing .

target.value: 150 Disseminations submitted to ML/FT investigating authorities

title.narrative: Outcome 2: Capacity of competent authorities (namely Ethiopian Financial Intelligence Centre (EFIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the AG’ Office to detect, investigate and prosecute ML/FT cases is strengthened.
Number of disseminations by the FIC that are used by ML/FT investigation and prosecuting authorities

target.value: 50 Disseminations by the FIC used by ML/FT investigation and prosecution authorities

title.narrative: Outcome 3: Capacity of competent authorities (especially the AG’s Office, Ministry of Revenues, Customs Commission, police crime prevention sector and EFIC) to collaborate with foreign counterparts (exchange information and assistance) to curb IFFs and cross-border ML enhanced.
Number of collaborative interactions with foreign counterparts to curb IFFs and cross border ML/ membership in frameworks for collaboration in curbing IFFs and cross border ML

target.value: Ethiopia enters into MLA and/or information sharing treaties with an additional four countries and is actively cooperating on ML and IFF cases (18 countries in total)

title.narrative: Outcome 1: Ethiopian compliance with Financial Action Task Force (FATF) recommendations improved.
Number of FATF recommendations where compliance deficiencies remain.

target.value: Ethiopia has made substantial progress in complying fully with FATF Recommendations and deficiencies remain with respect to only 4 recommendations

title.narrative: Output 1.1 Capacity of the Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and Countering Financing Terrorism (CFT) competent authorities to ensure the implementation of risk-informed approaches to ML and FT by reporting entities is enhanced.
Number of ML and FT risk assessments adopted by sectors.

target.value: Completion of 10 more risk assessments and risk mitigation systems to ML/FT (60 in total)
30 risk assessments completed by sector and approved by the supervisory bodies

actual.value: No sectoral risk assessments expected or completed.

target.value: Completion of 10 more risk assessments and risk mitigation systems to ML/FT (40 in total)

actual.value: No sectoral risk assessments expected or completed.

target.value: Completion of 10 more risk assessments and risk mitigation systems to ML/FT (50 in total)

actual.value: Progress made: 2 sectoral risk assessments conducted by the FIS (on legal persons, virtual assets and virtual asset service providers). In total 13 sectoral risk assessments completed.

title.narrative: Output 2.2: Improved prosecution of ML/FT cases at federal and regional levels
Rate of ML and FT cases prosecutions at federal and regional levels

target.value: At least 25% of invested financial crime cases prosecuted as ML or FT

actual.value: 59.7% of invested financial crime cases prosecuted as ML or FT

target.value: At least 30% of invested financial crime cases prosecuted as ML or FT

actual.value: 60% of invested financial crime cases prosecuted as ML or FT

target.value: At least 40% of invested financial crime cases prosecuted as ML or FT
At least 15% of invested financial crime cases prosecuted as ML or FT

actual.value: Updated data from the FIC and FBI not yet available. 2 training workshops for investigators and prosecutors were held
